prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We propose to observe for each of the targets the 3mm continuum emission, the NH2D 1(1,1)-1(0,1) line and the SiO(2-1) line emission.
For Band 3 the correlator should be setup with one banseband in the lower side-band centered at the N2D 1(1,1)0s-1(0,1)0a line at 85.93 GHz and include the SiO v=0 J=2-1 line at 86.85 GHz, while the remaining three baseband are assigned for the continuum with 2 GHz bandwidth centered around 88.0 GHz (LSB), 98.5 GHz and 100.5 GHz (USB).
The molecular-line basebands should have a bandwith and resolution enough to achieve a velocity resolution of ~ 0.2 km/s, after Hanning smoothing for the purpose of resolving the hyperfine structure. This means for both lines a bandwith of 58.594 MHz and a resolution of 61.035 kHz.
According to the latest Herschel-PACS 160um image our target have an angular size (beam-corrected FWHM) of ~ 9". To properly cover it, we propose to observe a 35" x 35" field centered on each source. This requires mosaics of 3 pointings with the 12m-array for Band 3 using the default 0.48 main beam separation.
We require an angular resolution of 1" enough to resolve single prestellar and protostellar cores within the MDCs: ~ 1700 AU at the distance of NGC6-334, 1.75 kpc. This is the current scale others studies on fragmentation have aimed for. We also need to cover the most spatial scales possible up to 9", the observable size of our targets, to recover any possible velocity structure in the MDCs and this is within the reach of the 12m-array without ACA.
The minimum peak intensity for the lines emission we expect is 50 mJy for the NH2D fragments. We extrapolated this from Pillai et al. 2011 observations with PdBi and scale by our two-times closer distance and a beam five times smaller. Their study was also on protostellar and we will we aim at denser material since we target the denser cores inside the IRDCs. To achieve a reliable detection of 5-sigma we ask for a sensitivity of 10 mJy.
Since the continuum observations are simultaneous to the molecular lines observations, in the time calculated by the OT to achieve the desired line sensitivity it calculates that the continuum sensitivity we will reach is 30uJy. Assuming a temperature of 13K and a dust opacity index beta = 2, this represents a 5-sigma mass limit of ~ 0.75 Msun. This is slightly above commun studies threshold (~ 0.5 Msun) and we should be able to compare with them.
We will adopt a system-defined calibration.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose to observe five selected Massive Dense Cores (100Msun, 0.1pc) using Band 3 for the 3mm continuum emission, the NH2D 1(1,1)-1(0,1) line and the SiO(2-1) line emission at a resolution of 1".
Our goal is to resolve and analyze the fragmentation and distribution of subcores in the dust continuum emission and subcores in the NH2D cold gas. Many observables can be infered and constrain the main opposing models of massive star formation. We will also confirm protostellar/prestellar assumptions regarding outflows and NH2D destruction during subcore evolution.
The MDCS are located in NGC-6334, a well-known massive star forming complex with filamentary structures, infrared-dark clouds and dense cores embedded inside the filaments, that is close enough (1.75kpc) to observe massive stars in the making.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Observatoire Astronomique Marseille Provence, Laboratoire d'Astrophysique de Marseille

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Observatoire Marseille Provence, Astrophysical Laboratory, Marseille
